p: Our results confirmed the in vitro antibacterial, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory activities of M. didyma EO. A diet supplemented with M. didyma EO significantly increased mouse BW and suggested good biological activity in broilers. EO has good potential as an alternative to synthetic antibiotics used in animal nutrition. Future research must explore M. didyma EO in vivo antibacterial activity against E. coli and C. perfringens. Nonetheless, the different dosages of M. didyma EO in the starter, growth, and finisher phases of the broiler diets remain to be tested to determine the optimal concentrations.
